questions.text: Which of the following hormone or metabolic fuel level in blood is increased during the onset of starvation?
questions.solution:
• Option A, Option C, Option D: The level of insulin, glucose & glycogen are decreased during onset of starvation.
  • Option B: The level of glucagon, fatty acid & ketone body are increased during onset of starvation.

Relative changes in plasma hormones and metabolic fuels during the onset of starvation


Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 14, page number 139

questions.text: Glucose and mannose are:
questions.solution:
• Isomers differing as a result of variations in configuration of the -OH and -H on carbon atoms 2, 3, and 4 of glucose are known as epimers.
  • Biologically, the most important epimers of glucose are mannose (epimerized at carbon 2) and galactose (epimerized at carbon 4).

So Option A is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 15, page number 143

questions.text: All are fates of the carbon skeletons that remain after transamination, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: After deamination, amino nitrogen is excreted as urea, not carbon skeleton.
  • The carbon skeletons that remain after transamination may,
  • be oxidized to CO2 via the citric acid cycle (Option B)
  • be used to synthesize glucose (gluconeogenesis), (Option C)
  • form ketone bodies or acetyl-CoA, which may be oxidized or used for synthesis of fatty acids. (Option D)

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 14, page number 131

questions.text: The synthesis of triglycerides take place in:
questions.solution:
• Compartmentation of pathways in separate subcellular compartments or organelles permits integration and regulation of metabolism.
  • Option A: Glycolysis, the pentose phosphate pathway, and fatty acid synthesis all occur in the cytosol.
  • Option B: The mitochondrion contains the enzymes of the citric acid cycle, β-oxidation of fatty acids and ketogenesis, as well as the respiratory chain and ATP synthase.
  • Option C: The membranes of the endoplasmic reticulum contain the enzyme system for triacylglycerol synthesis.
  • Option D: The ribosomes are responsible for protein synthesis.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 14, Page number 134

questions.text: Amylose:
questions.solution:
• Starch is a homopolymer of glucose forming an α-glucosidic chain, called a glucosan or glucan. It is made up of contain two main constituents are amylose (13-20%) & amylopectin (80-87%). It is the most important dietary carbohydrate in cereals, potatoes, legumes, and other vegetables.
  • Option A & Option D: It is homopolymer of glucose contain an α-glucosidic chain.
  • Option B: Amylose is nonbranching helical structure and amylopectin consists of branched chains.
  • Amylopectin consists of 24 to 30 glucose residues with α1 → 4 linkages in the chains and by α1 → 6 linkages at the branch points.
  • Option C: Starch contain two main constituents are amylose (13-20%) & amylopectin (80-87%). So, amylopectin is major constituent of starch, not amylose.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 15, page number 145

choices.text: Niacin is electron acceptor for succinate dehydrogenase
Riboflavin is electron acceptor for malate dehydrogenase
Niacin is electron donor for α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is representing appropriate role of specific vitamin in TCA cycle?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Niacin, as NAD+, is the electron acceptor for isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase.
  • Option B: Riboflavin, as FAD, is the electron acceptor for succinate dehydrogenase;
  • Option C: Thiamine, as thiamine diphosphate, is the coenzyme for decarboxylation in the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reaction.
  • Option D: Niacin, as NAD+, is the electron acceptor for α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (not donor).

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 16, page number 153

questions.text: Vitamin B1 deficiency leads to Lactic acidosis due to impaired activity of enzyme:
questions.solution:
• Vitamin B1 is required as cofactor for enzyme Pyruvate dehydrogenase which converts pyruvate into acetyl CoA. As result of vitamin B1 deficiency, activity of this enzyme is reduced, which lead to accumulation of pyruvate which convert into lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 17 Page number 157

questions.text: Pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex:
questions.solution:
• Option A: The oxidation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA is the irreversible route from glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.
  • Option B: Pyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to acetyl-CoA by an enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH).
  • Option C: This pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex of the citric acid cycle.
  • Option D: PDH is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 17, page number 161

choices.text: Catalyses the formation of a glycoside bond between C-1 of the glucose of UDPGlc and C-4 of a terminal glucose residue of glycogen
Transfers part of 1 → 4 chain to a neighbouring chain to form a 1 → 6 linkage
Transfers a trisaccharide unit from one branch to the other, exposing the 1 → 6 branch point
Catalyses the formation of a glycoside bond between C-1 of the new glucose and C-6 of a terminal glucose residue of glycogen

questions.text: Action of branching enzyme during glycogen synthesis is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glycogen synthase catalyses the formation of a glycoside bond between C-1 of the glucose of UDPGlc and C-4 of a terminal glucose residue of glycogen, liberating UDP
  • Option B: When a growing chain is at least 11 glucose residues long, branching enzyme transfers a part of the 1 → 4 chain (at least six glucose residues) to a neighbouring chain to form a 1 → 6 linkage, establishing a branch point. The branches grow by further additions of 1 → 4-glucosyl units and further branching.
  • Option C: A glucan Transferases that transfers a trisaccharide unit from one branch to the other, exposing the 1 → 6 branch point
  • Option D: Glycogen synthase catalyses the formation of a glycoside bond between C-1 of the glucose of UDPGlc (source of glucose in glycogen synthesis is UDPGlc, not free glucose) and C-6 of a terminal glucose residue of glycogen.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 18, page number 165

questions.text: All of the following can form glucose by process of gluconeogenesis, except:
questions.solution:
• Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose from noncarbohydrate precursors. The major substrates are the glucogenic amino acids, lactate (Option A), glycerol (Option D), and propionate.
  • Major glucogenic amino acid is alanine, which can form glucose during gluconeogenesis. (Option B)
  • Option C: Glycogen is a carbohydrate that can convert into glucose during fasting by process of glycogenolysis.
  • So Option C is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 19, page number 173

questions.text: Methyl malonic aciduria occurs due to deficiency of enzyme:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Propionate is a major precursor of glucose in ruminants; it enters gluconeogenesis via the citric acid cycle. After esterification with CoA, propionyl-CoA is carboxylated to d-methylmalonyl-CoA, catalysed by propionyl-CoA carboxylase, a biotin-dependent enzyme.
  • In nonruminants, including human beings, propionate arises from the β-oxidation of odd chain fatty acids that occur in ruminant lipids, as well as the oxidation of isoleucine and the side chain of cholesterol, and is a (relatively minor) substrate for gluconeogenesis.
  • Option C: Methylmalonyl-CoA racemase catalyses the conversion of d-methylmalonyl-CoA to l-methylmalonyl-CoA.
  • Option B: l-methylmalonyl-CoA then undergoes isomerization to succinyl-CoA catalysed by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase.
  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme, and in deficiency, methylmalonic acid is excreted in the urine (methylmalonic aciduria).
  • Option D: Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme involve in gluconeogenesis. It converts pyruvate into oxaloacetate. It is not involved in propionate metabolism.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 19, page number 174

questions.text: Which of the following form is present in crystalline glucose?
questions.solution:
• Alpha- and beta-anomers: The ring structure of an aldose is a hemiacetal, since it is formed by reaction between an aldehyde and an alcohol group. Similarly, the ring structure of a ketose is a hemiketal.
  • Crystalline glucose is α-d-glucopyranose.
  • The cyclic structure is retained in the solution, but isomerism occurs about position 1, the carbonyl or anomeric carbon atom, to give a mixture of α-glucopyranose (38%) and β-glucopyranose (62%). Less than 0.3% is represented by α- and β-anomers of glucofuranose.

So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 15, page number 143

questions.text: Which among the following is the major tissue which produces glucose from noncarbohydrate sources during starvation?
questions.solution:
• Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose from noncarbohydrate precursors. The major substrates are the glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.
  • Liver and kidney are the major gluconeogenic tissues; the kidney may contribute up to 40% of total glucose synthesis in the fasting state and more in starvation. (Option D)
  • The key gluconeogenic enzymes are expressed in the small intestine, but it is unclear whether or not there is significant glucose production by the intestine in the fasting state, although propionate arising from intestinal bacterial fermentation of carbohydrates is a substrate for gluconeogenesis in enterocyte. (Option A)
  • Gluconeogenesis do not occur in Brain and skeletal muscle. (Option B & Option C)

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 19, page number 173

questions.text: The irreversible reactions of glycolysis are reversed by different enzyme in gluconeogenesis. The following are pairs of enzymes which catalyses irreversible step of glycolysis and same step reversed by gluconeogenic enzyme. Which of the following pair is not correctly match?
questions.solution:
• Option A: In glycolysis, Glucose converts into glucose 6 phosphate by hexokinase or glucokinase (irreversible step). During gluconeogenesis, the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose is catalysed by glucose-6-phosphatase. It is present in liver and kidney, but absent from muscle, which, therefore, cannot export glucose into the bloodstream.
  • Option B: In glycolysis, Fructose 6 phosphate converts into fructose 1,6 biphosphate by phosphofructokinase (irreversible step). During gluconeogenesis, the conversion of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate to fructose6-phosphate, for the reversal of glycolysis, is catalysed by fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase.
  • Option C: In glycolysis, Phosphoenolpyruvate converts into pyruvate by pyruvate kinase (irreversible step). During gluconeogenesis, reversal of the reaction catalysed by pyruvate kinase in glycolysis involves two endothermic reactions. Mitochondrial pyruvate carboxylase catalyses the carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, an ATP-requiring reaction in which the vitamin biotin is the coenzyme. The resultant oxaloacetate is reduced to malate, exported from the mitochondrion into the cytosol and there oxidized back to oxaloacetate. A second enzyme, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase, catalyses the decarboxylation and phosphorylation of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate using GTP as the phosphate donor.
  • Option D: In glycolysis, Phosphoenolpyruvate converts into pyruvate by pyruvate kinase (irreversible step). During gluconeogenesis, reversal of the reaction catalysed by pyruvate kinase in glycolysis involves two enzymes pyruvate carboxylase and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase.
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase convert pyruvate into acetyl CoA, not involved in reversing the reaction of pyruvate kinase.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 19, page number 172

questions.text: All of the following processes are increased by Glucagon, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glycogenesis is increased by insulin, not glucagon. Glucagon decreases glycogenesis.
  • Option B, Option C & Option D: Gluconeogenesis, Glycogenolysis & Ketogenesis are increased by glucagon.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 19., page number179

questions.text: Which of the following is a simple lipid?
questions.solution:
• Option B: Simple lipids include fats and waxes which are esters of fatty acids with various alcohols: a) Fats: Esters of fatty acids with glycerol. Oils are fats in the liquid state.
  • b) Waxes: Esters of fatty acids with higher molecular weight monohydric alcohols.
  • Option C & Option D: Complex lipids are esters of fatty acids, which always contain an alcohol and one or more fatty acids, but which also have other groups. They can be divided into three types:
  • Phospholipids: Contain a phosphoric acid residue. They frequently have nitrogen-containing bases (eg, choline) and other substituents. In many phospholipids the alcohol is glycerol (glycerophospholipids), but in sphingophospholipids it is sphingosine, which contains an amino group.
  • b) Glycolipids (glycosphingolipids): Contain a fatty acid, sphingosine, and carbohydrate.
  • c) Other complex lipids: These include lipids such as sulfolipids and amino lipids. Lipoproteins may also be placed in this category.
  • Option A: Derived lipids are formed from the hydrolysis of both simple and complex lipids. They include fatty acids, glycerol, steroids, other alcohols, fatty aldehydes, ketone bodies, hydrocarbons, lipid-soluble vitamins and micronutrients, and hormones. Some of these (eg, free fatty acids, glycerol) also act as precursor lipids in the formation of simple and complex lipids.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 21, page number 196

questions.text: Which of the following is an omega 6 fatty acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Oleic acid (C18:1;9) is Omega 9 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option B: Linoleic acid (C18:2;9,12) is Omega 6 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option C: Alpha linolenic acid (C18:3;9,12,15) is Omega 3 unsaturated fatty acid.
  • Option D: Cervonic acid (C22:6;4,7,10,13,16,19) is Omega 3 unsaturated fatty acid.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 21, page number 197

questions.text: Ceramide is made up of:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glycerol + FA + Phosphate à Phosphatidic acid
  • Option B: Phosphatidic acid + Choline à Phophatidyl choline (lecithin)
  • Option C: Sphingosine + Fatty acid + Phosphate + Choline à Phophatidyl sphingol (Sphingomyelin)
  • Option D: Sphingosine + Fatty acid à Ceramide

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 21, page number 200

choices.text: Used to shorten the side chain of cholesterol in bile acid formation
Linked directly to phosphorylation and the generation of ATP
Enzymes are repressed by high fat diet

questions.text: A peroxisomal β-oxidation are:
questions.solution:
• A modified form of β-oxidation is found in peroxisomes and leads to the breakdown of very-long-chain fatty acids (eg, C20, C22) with the formation of acetyl-CoA and H2O2, which is broken down by catalase.
  • Option A: Another role of peroxisomal β-oxidation is to shorten the side chain of cholesterol in bile acid formation. Peroxisomes also take part in the synthesis of ether glycerolipids, cholesterol, and dolichol.
  • Option B: This system does not attack shorter-chain fatty acids; the β-oxidation sequence ends at octanoyl-CoA. Octanoyl and acetyl groups are both further oxidized in mitochondria.
  • Option C: This system is not linked directly to phosphorylation and the generation of ATP.
  • Option D: The peroxisomal enzymes are induced by high-fat diets and in some species by hypolipidemic drugs such as clofibrate.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 21, page number 210

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are used for synthesis of ketone body formation, except:
questions.solution:
• The enzymes responsible for ketone body formation (Ketogenesis) are associated mainly with the mitochondria.
  • Option A: Condensation of acetoacetyl-CoA with another molecule of acetyl-CoA by 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA) synthase forms HMG-CoA.
  • Option B: HMG CoA reductase is an enzyme involved in cholesterol biosynthesis. Not involved in ketogenesis.
  • Option C: HMG-CoA lyase then causes acetyl-CoA to split off from the HMG-CoA, leaving free acetoacetate.
  • Option D: Acetoacetyl CoA is formed when two acetyl-CoA molecules produced via fatty acid breakdown condense to form acetoacetyl-CoA by a reversal of the thiolase reaction and may also arise directly from the terminal four carbons of a fatty acid during β-oxidation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 21, page number 212

questions.text: Normal ketone bodies level in blood is very negligible (less than 0.6 mmol/L). But the oxidative machinery becomes saturated if blood level of ketone bodies rises to a concentration of:
questions.solution:
• 1 mol of acetoacetate or 3-hydroxbutyrate yields 19 or 21.5 mol of ATP, respectively, by ketolysis (oxidation of ketone bodies).
  • If the blood level of ketone bodies rises to a concentration of ~12 mmol/L, the oxidative machinery becomes saturated and at this stage, a large proportion of oxygen consumption may be accounted for by their oxidation.
  • In moderate ketonemia, the loss of ketone bodies via the urine is only a few percent of the total ketone body production and utilization. Since there are renal threshold-like effects (there is not a true threshold) that vary between species and individuals, measurement of the ketonemia, not the ketonuria, is the preferred method of assessing the severity of ketosis

So Option D is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 21, page number 213

questions.text: Which of the following is a hydrophilic amino acid?
questions.solution:
• Option A, Option B, Option D: Phenyl alanine, Tyrosine and Tryptophan are hydrophobic amino acids.
  • Option C: Threonine is hydrophilic amino acid.
  • The R groups of amino acids can be characterized as being either hydrophilic or hydrophobic; properties that affect their location in a protein's mature folded conformation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 3, page number 17

questions.text: Which of the following biologically important peptide contain atypical non-α peptide bond?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Carnitine is transport protein present, help in transport of activated long chain fatty acid from cytoplasm to mitochondria for oxidation. It is a derivatives of amino acid lysine.
  • Option B: The amino terminal glutamate of glutathione, a tripeptide that participates in the metabolism of xenobiotics and the reduction of disulfide bonds, is linked to cysteine by a non-α peptide bond.
  • In mammals, any peptide chains contain standard α-amino acids linked by standard peptide bonds. Other peptides may, however, contain nonprotein amino acids, derivatives of the protein amino acids, or amino acids linked by an atypical peptide bond. eg glutathione
  • Option C: Glucagon is a peptide hormone, made up of standard amino acid and linked together by standard peptide bond. It is involved in regulation of blood sugar level.
  • Option D: Creatine is protein present in muscle. It is made up of glycine, arginine and methionine. All linked together by standard peptide bond.

  • Also the amino terminal glutamate of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is cyclized to pyroglutamic acid, and the carboxyl group of the carboxyl terminal prolyl residue is amidated.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 3, page number 20

questions.text: All of the following peptides contain non standard amino acid, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Aquaporins are integral membrane proteins that act as water channels. It is a large protein made up of standard amino acids.
  • Option B & Option C: The nonprotein amino acids d-phenylalanine and ornithine are present in the cyclic peptide antibiotics tyrocidin and gramicidin S.
  • Option D: The heptapeptide opioids dermorphin and deltophorin in the skin of South American tree frogs contain d-tyrosine and d-alanine.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 3, page number 21

questions.text: Identify the bond in below image.
questions.solution:
Option A: The bond shown in above image is peptide bond

Alpha carboxyl group of one amino acid reacts with alpha amino group of other amino acid to form a CO-NH linkage, which known as peptide bond.

Characteristics of a peptide bond

  • Partial double bond because distance is 1.32 A° which is midway between single bond (1.42A°) and a double bond (1.27A°).
  • Trans in nature
  • Rigid, No freedom of rotation because of partial double bond character (Option C)
  • But side chains are free to rotate on either side of the peptide bond. The angles of rotation is k/a Ramchandran angles. It determine the spatial orientation of peptide chain.

Option B: Glycosidic bond is present between monosaccharides in carbohydrates.

Option C: Ester bond is present between fatty acid and alcohol in lipids.

Option D: Hydrogen bond is present between nitrogen bases during formation of DNA double helix.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 3, page number 21

questions.text: Collagen does not undergo:
questions.solution:
• Collagen is a fibrous proteins. It is found as components of skin, connective tissue, blood vessel walls, sclera and cornea of the eye.
  • It serve structural functions in the body.
  • Exhibits special mechanical properties, resulting from its unique structure, which are obtained by combining specific amino acids containing polypeptide chain into regular, secondary structural elements.
  • It mainly synthesized in fibroblasts, osteoblasts, and chondroblasts.
  • It undergo many post translational modification like hydroxylation, glycosylation etc
  • Option A: Carboxylation doesn't occur in collagen, it will seen during post translational modification of clotting factors.
  • Option B: Collagen contains hydroxyproline (Hyp) and hydroxylysine (Hyl), which are not present in most other proteins.
  • These residues result from hydroxylation of some of the proline and lysine residues after their incorporation into polypeptide chains. Hydroxyproline is important in stabilizing the triple-helical structure of collagen because it maximizes interchain hydrogen bond formation.
  • Option C: The hydroxyl group of the hydroxy lysine residues of collagen may be enzymatically glycosylated.
  • Most commonly, glucose and galactose are sequentially attached to the polypeptide chain prior to triple-helix formation.
  • Option D: The fibrillar array of collagen molecules serves as a substrate for lysyl oxidase. This extracellular enzyme oxidatively deaminates some of the lysyl and hydroxylysyl residues in collagen.
  • The reactive aldehydes that result (allysine and hydroxylysine) ® condense with lysyl or hydroxylysyl residues in neighboring collagen molecules ® form covalent cross-links
  • This cross-linking is essential for achieving the tensile strength necessary for the proper functioning of connective tissue.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 5, page number 43

choices.text: Synthesis of glutamate by reductive amidation of α-ketoglutarate
Synthesis of glutamine by reductive amidation of α-ketoglutarate
Synthesis of alanine by transamination of pyruvate
Synthesis of aspartate by transamination of oxaloacetate

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding biosynthesis of non essential amino acid, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Glutamate is formed by the reductive amidation of the citric acid cycle α-ketoglutarate, a reaction catalysed by mitochondrial glutamate dehydrogenase. The reaction strongly favors glutamate synthesis, which lowers the concentration of cytotoxic ammonium ion.
  • Option B: The amidation of glutamate to glutamine catalysed by glutamine synthetase involves the intermediate formation of γ-glutamyl phosphate.
  • Option C: Transamination of pyruvate forms alanine.
  • Option D: Similarly, transamination of oxaloacetate forms aspartate amino acid.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 27, page number 264

choices.text: Interconvert pairs of α-amino acids and α-keto acids.
Alanine transaminase is present rich amount in heart

questions.text: Transaminase enzyme:
questions.solution:
• Transamination transfers α-amino nitrogen to α-ketoglutarate and forming glutamate by enzyme transaminase.
  • Option A: Catalyses freely reversible reactions.
  • Option B: Requires PLP (Pyridoxal phosphate as coenzyme)
  • Option C: Transamination reactions catalysed by transaminase enzyme will interconvert pairs of α-amino acids and α-keto acids.
  • Option D: Alanine transaminase (ALT) is present in liver, so in liver diseases a level of ALT in blood is increased.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 28, page number 273

choices.text: N terminal valines of haemoglobin β chains
C terminal valines of haemoglobin β chains
N terminal valines of haemoglobin α chains
C terminal valines of haemoglobin α chains

questions.text: Glycated Haemoglobin (HbA1c) is formed by binding of glucose with:
questions.solution:
GLYCATED HEMOGLOBIN (HbA1c )

  • Blood glucose that enters the erythrocytes can form a covalent adduct with the ε-amino groups of lysyl residues and the N-terminal valines of hemoglobin β chains, a process referred to as glycation.
  • Unlike glycosylation, glycation is not enzyme catalyzed. The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood glucose concentration.
  • Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6 to 8 weeks. Measurement of HbA1c therefore provides valuable information for management of diabetes mellitus.

So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 6, page number 55

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glutamate dehydrogenase reaction?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Transfer of amino nitrogen to α-ketoglutarate forms l-glutamate done by Hepatic l-glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), which can use either NAD+ or NADP+, releases this nitrogen as ammonia.
  • Option B & Option C: Liver GDH activity is allosterically inhibited by ATP, GTP, and NADH, and is activated by ADP.
  • Option D: The GDH reaction is freely reversible, and also functions in amino acid biosynthesis.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 28, page number 273

questions.text: Rate limiting enzyme of urea cycle is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Arginase breakdown arginine into urea and ornithine in last step.
  • Option B: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I initiate urea biosynthesis.
  • Condensation of CO2, ammonia, and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate is catalyzed by mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I.
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle, is active only in the presence of N-acetylglutamate, an allosteric activator that enhances the affinity of the synthetase for ATP.
  • Option C: A cytosolic form of this enzyme, carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II, uses glutamine rather than ammonia as the nitrogen donor and functions in pyrimidine biosynthesis.
  • Option D: l-Ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyses transfer of the carbamoyl group of carbamoyl phosphate to ornithine, forming citrulline and orthophosphate.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 28, page number 275

questions.text: All of the following component is required during biosynthesis of urea in human, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A & Option B: Condensation of CO2, ammonia, and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate is catalyzed by mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I during first reaction in urea cycle.
  • Option C: Argininosuccinate synthetase links aspartate and citrulline via the amino group of aspartate. Aspartate provides the second nitrogen of urea.
  • Option D: Glutamate is not used in urea cycle during production of urea.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 28, page number 275

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of enzyme arginase?
questions.solution:
• Cleavage of arginine releases Urea & reforms Ornithine in last step of urea cycle.
  • Hydrolytic cleavage of the guanidino group of arginine, catalysed by liver arginase, releases urea. The other product, ornithine, re-enters liver mitochondria and participates in additional rounds of urea synthesis.
  • Ornithine and lysine are potent inhibitors of arginase, and compete with arginine.
  • Arginine also serves as the precursor of the potent muscle relaxant nitric oxide (NO) in a Ca2+ dependent reaction catalysed by NO synthetase.
  • So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 28, page number 276

questions.text: A citrulline level in plasma, urine and CSF are increased in metabolic defect of enzyme:
questions.solution:
• Option A: In addition to patients who lack detectable argininosuccinate synthetase activity, a 25-fold elevated Km for citrulline has been reported. In the resulting citrullinemia, plasma and cerebrospinal fluid citrulline levels are elevated, and 1 to 2 g of citrulline are excreted daily.
  • Option B: Argininosuccinic aciduria, accompanied by elevated levels of argininosuccinate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, is associated with friable, tufted hair (trichorrhexis nodosa). Both early- and late-onset types are known. The metabolic defect is in argininosuccinate lyase. Diagnosis by the measurement of erythrocyte argininosuccinate lyase activity can be performed on umbilical cord blood or amniotic fluid cells.
  • Option C: Hyperargininaemia is an autosomal recessive defect in the gene for arginase. Unlike other urea cycle disorders, the first symptoms of hyperargininemia typically do not appear until age 2 to 4 years. Blood and cerebrospinal fluid levels of arginine are elevated. The urinary amino acid pattern, which resembles that of lysine-cystinuria, may reflect competition by arginine with lysine and cysteine for reabsorption in the renal tubule.
  • Option D: The X-chromosome-linked deficiency termed 'hyperammonemia type 2' reflects a defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase. The mothers also exhibit hyperammonemia and an aversion to high-protein foods. Levels of glutamine are elevated in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, probably as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 28, page number 278

questions.text: Fumarate is an intermediate that results from catabolism of amino acid:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Tryptophan when catabolized it produces an intermediate acetoacetyl CoA or acetyl CoA.
  • Option B: Threonine when catabolized it produces an intermediate acetyl CoA.
  • Option C: Tyrosine and phenyl alanine catabolism produces an intermediate fumarate.
  • Option D: Proline is converted into glutamate and then in to alpha keto glutarate.

Reference: Harper' s illustrated biochemistry 31 < sup > st < /sup> edition Chapter 29, page number 281

questions.text: A one year old child was observed to have a lack of pigmentation, blue eyes, white hair and photophobia. Which of the following enzyme deficiency found in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Option C: Above clinical presentation is correlated with albinism, which occurs due to deficiency of enzyme tyrosine which converts tyrosine into melanin.
  • Option A: The probable metabolic defect in type II tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) is tyrosine aminotransferase (reaction 1 in below image). Alternate metabolites of tyrosine are also excreted in type II tyrosinemia.
  • Option B: The probable metabolic defect in type I tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis) is at fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Therapy employs a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine. Untreated acute and chronic tyrosinosis leads to death from liver failure.
  • Option D: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase, the enzyme that catalyses reaction 3 in below image. The urine darkens on exposure to air due to oxidation of excreted homogentisate. Late in the disease, there is arthritis and connective tissue pigmentation (ochronosis) due to oxidation of homogentisate to benzoquinone acetate, which polymerizes and binds to connective tissue.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 30, page number 300

questions.text: Which of following amino acid used to detect folic acid deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Catabolism of histidine proceeds via urocanate, 4-imidazolone 5-propionate, and N-formiminoglutamate (FIGLU). Formimino group transfer to tetrahydrofolate forms glutamate, then α-ketoglutarate.

  • In folic acid deficiency, transfer of the Formimino group is impaired, and FIGLU is excreted. Excretion of FIGLU following a dose of histidine thus can be used to detect folic acid deficiency.
  • Benign disorders of histidine catabolism include histidinemia and urocanic aciduria associated with impaired histidase and urocanase, respectively.

So Option B is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 29, page number 282

questions.text: All of the following are synthesized from tyrosine, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Melanin is also synthesized from tyrosine by enzyme tyrosinase.
  • Option B: Serotonin is produced from tryptophane.

  • Option C & Option D: Neural cells convert tyrosine to epinephrine and norepinephrine. While dopa is also an intermediate in the formation of melanin, different enzymes hydroxylate tyrosine in melanocytes. DOPA decarboxylase, a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme, forms dopamine. Subsequent hydroxylation, catalysed by dopamine β-oxidase, then forms norepinephrine. In the adrenal medulla, phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase utilizes S-adenosylmethionine to methylate the primary amine of norepinephrine, forming epinephrine.

Tyrosine is also a precursor of triiodothyronine and thyroxine.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 30, page number 300

questions.text: Coenzymes are:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Almost all enzymes are protein in nature except ribozymes which is RNA in nature

They are heat labile in nature, not heat stable.

  • Option B: A non-protein part of enzyme is termed as Coenzyme. Coenzyme is a low molecular weight organic substance. Coenzymes are heat stable.
  • Option C: Heat labile protein molecules are termed as enzymes.
  • Option D: Coenzyme are heat stable non protein molecules.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 7, page number 58

questions.text: Enzymes are classified based on:
questions.solution:
• International Union of Biochemistry (IUB) developed a system of enzyme nomenclature in which each enzyme has a unique name and code number that identify the type of reaction catalysed. Enzymes are grouped into the following six classes:
  1. Oxidoreductases-enzymes that catalyse oxidations and reductions.
  2. Transferases-enzymes that catalyse transfer of moieties such as glycosyl, methyl, or phosphoryl groups.
  3. Hydrolases-enzymes that catalyse hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.
  4. Lyases-enzymes that catalyse cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, generating double bonds.
  5. Isomerases-enzymes that catalyse geometric or structural changes within a molecule.
  6. Ligases-enzymes that catalyse the joining together (ligation) of two molecules in reactions coupled to the hydrolysis of ATP.

So Option C is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 7, page number 57

questions.text: A competitive inhibitor has:
questions.solution:
• A competitive inhibitor has no effect on Vmax but raises Km. Whereas simple noncompetitive inhibitors lower Vmax but do not affect Km.

So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 8, page number 77

choices.text: Effect of pH on enzyme activity
Effect of substrate concentration on enzyme catalysed reaction
Behaviour of enzymes that exhibit cooperative binding of substrate
Effect of enzyme concentration on enzyme catalysis

questions.text: The Hill Equation describes:
questions.solution:
• The Hill equation describes the behavior of enzymes that exhibit cooperative binding of substrate
  • While most enzymes display the simple saturation kinetics and are adequately described by the Michaelis-Menten expression, some enzymes bind their substrates in a cooperative fashion analogous to the binding of oxygen by hemoglobin. Cooperative behavior is an exclusive property of multimeric enzymes that bind substrate at multiple sites. For enzymes that display positive cooperativity in binding the substrate, the shape of the curve that relates changes in Vi to changes in [S] is sigmoidal. Neither the Michaelis-Menten expression nor its derived plots can be used to evaluate cooperative kinetics. Enzymologists therefore employ a graphic representation of the Hill equation originally derived to describe the cooperative binding of O2 by haemoglobin.

So option C is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 8, page number 76

questions.text: Km value indicates:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Km denotes the affinity of enzyme for substrate.
  • Option B: Km value is substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity.
  • Option C: Specificity of substrate is decided by enzyme specificity.
  • Option D: Km will not indicating saturating concentration of substrate.

Michaelis Constant (Km)

  • Km value is substrate concentration (moles/L) at half-maximal velocity.
  • It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules (irrespective of enzyme concentration) are bound with substrate molecule at that particular substrate concentration.
  • Km is the Signature of the Enzyme.
  • Km denotes the affinity of enzyme for substrate. The lesser the numerical value of Km, the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate is more.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 8, Page number 74

questions.text: A 12 year old male child presented with photosensitivity, abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptom. Urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and faecal protoporphyrin IX found to be increased. Genetic analysis reveals deficiency of enzyme Protoporphyrinogen oxidase (EC 1.3.3.4). Which of the following types of porphyria is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase leads to acute intermittent porphyria.
  • Option B: Protoporphyrinogen oxidase defect leads to Variegate porphyria.
  • Option C: Coproporphyrinogen oxidase deficient leads to Hereditary coproporphyria
  • Option D: Uroporphyrinogen III synthase leads to congenital erythropoietic porphyria.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 31, page number 310

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of conjugated hyper bilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
• Option A, Option B & Option C: Physiological jaundice, Gilbert syndrome, Crigler Najjar syndrome type I & type II are causes of unconjugated hyper bilirubinemia.
  • Neonatal Physiologic Jaundice: The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of neonatal physiologic jaundice results from accelerated hemolysis and an immature hepatic system for the uptake, conjugation, and secretion of bilirubin.
  • In this transient condition, bilirubin glucuronosyltransferase activity, and probably also synthesis of UDP-glucuronate, are reduced. When the plasma concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds that which can be tightly bound by albumin (20-25 mg/dL), bilirubin can penetrate the blood-brain barrier.
  • If left untreated, the resulting hyperbilirubinemic toxic encephalopathy, or kernicterus, can result in mental retardation. Exposure of jaundiced neonates to blue light (phototherapy) promotes hepatic excretion of unconjugated bilirubin by converting some to derivatives that are excreted in the bile, and phenobarbital, a promoter of bilirubin metabolism, may be administered.

  • Option D: Dubin Johnson syndrome can lead to conjugated hyper bilirubinemia.
  • Dubin-Johnson Syndrome: This benign autosomal recessive disorder consists of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in childhood or during adult life. The hyperbilirubinemia is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the protein involved in the secretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 31, page number 313

questions.text: All of the following condition can lead to hypouricemia except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Liver is the major site of purine nucleotide biosynthesis, even liver provides purines and purine nucleosides for salvage and for utilization by tissues incapable of their biosynthesis. So liver cirrhosis will reduce purine nucleotide and their catabolism into uric acid is also reduced.
  • Option B: HGPRTase is an enzyme involved in salvage pathway. It converts Guanine & Hypoxanthine into GMP & IMP. Deficiency of HGPRTase (known as Lesch nyhan syndrome) leads to accumulation of Guanine & Hypoxanthine, which when catabolised leads to increase uric acid level (hyperuricemia)
  • Option C: Xanthine oxidase enzyme convert Hypoxanthine into Xanthine and Xanthine into Uric acid. So genetic defect in xanthine oxidase will reduce uric acid formation and lead to hypouricemia.
  • Option D: ADA (Adenosine deaminase) converts adenosine into inosine. This reaction is involved in catabolism of purine nucleotide. So defect in ADA is also associated with reduced uric acid production.
  • ADA defect is associated with an immunodeficiency disease in which both thymus-derived lymphocytes (T cells) and bone marrow- derived lymphocytes (B cells) are sparse and dysfunctional. Patients suffer from severe immunodeficiency. In the absence of enzyme replacement or bone marrow transplantation, infants often succumb to fatal infections.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 33, page number 335

questions.text: Human tissues can synthesize purine and pyrimidines from amphibolic compound to meet their physiologic demand. But RBC utilizes exogenous purine to form purine nucleotides because of inability to synthesize:
questions.solution:
• Liver, the major site of purine nucleotide biosynthesis, provides purines and purine nucleosides for salvage and for utilization by tissues incapable of their biosynthesis.
  • Human brain tissue has a low level of PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase and hence depends in part on exogenous purines.
  • Erythrocytes and polymorphonuclear leukocytes cannot synthesize 5-phosphoribosylamine and therefore also utilize exogenous purines to form nucleotides.

So Option A is correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 33, page number 330

choices.text: H1 is not a part of core histone molecules
H4 histone can be easily removed from chromatin by salt solution
Carboxyl terminal two-thirds of the histone molecules are hydrophilic
Amino terminal thirds are rich in acidic amino acids

questions.text: True regarding histone is:
questions.solution:
• Histones Are the Most Abundant Chromatin Proteins

Histones are a small family of closely related basic proteins.

  • Option A: The organizational unit of this soluble chromatin is the nucleosome. Nucleosomes contain four major types of histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and H4. The sequence and structures of all four histones, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, the so-called core histones that form the nucleosome, have been highly conserved between species, although variants of the histones exist and are used for specialized purposes. This extreme conservation implies that the function of histones is identical in all eukaryotes and that the entire molecule is involved quite specifically in carrying out this function.
  • The histones interact with each other in very specific ways. H3 and H4 form a tetramer containing two molecules of each (H3-H4)2, while H2A and H2B form dimers (H2A- H2B). Under physiologic conditions, these histone oligomers associate to form the histone octamer of the composition (H3-H4)2-(H2A-H2B)2.

  • Option B: H1 histones are the ones least tightly bound to chromatin and are, therefore, easily removed with a salt solution, after which chromatin becomes more soluble.
  • Option C & Option D: The carboxyl terminal two-thirds of the histone molecules are hydrophobic, while their amino terminal thirds are particularly rich in basic amino acids.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 35, page number 351

choices.text: Occurs during M phase of cell cycle

questions.text: All of the following are characteristic of DNA replication, except:
questions.solution:
• The process of copying the DNA is known as DNA replication.
  • Option A: Two new complimentary strands are synthesized from double stranded DNA molecule.
  • Out of them one goes to one daughter nucleus & other to second daughter nucleus.
  • So in daughter cell, one strand is derived from mother cell; while other strand is newly synthesized.
  • Thus old DNA strands are not degraded, but are conserved in daughter cell, so this is termed as Semiconservative
  • Option B: Occur from single stranded DNA (ssDNA) template after unwinding dsDNA.
  • Option C: In one strand, it is continuous and at other strand, its discontinuous
  • Option D: Occurs during S phase of cell cycle, so referred as Synthetic phase.

Salient features of DNA replication are:

  • Primary role of replication is to provide same genetic material (present in parent cell) to the daughter cells.
  • Occurs during S phase of cell cycle, so referred as Synthetic phase.
  • Two new complimentary strands are synthesized from double stranded DNA molecule.

Out of them one goes to one daughter nucleus & other to second daughter nucleus.

So in daughter cell, one strand is derived from mother cell; while other strand is newly synthesized.

Thus old DNA strands are not degraded, but are conserved in daughter cell, so this is termed as Semiconservative synthesis.

  • In one strand, it is continuous and at other strand, its discontinuous
  • Occur from single stranded DNA (ssDNA) template after unwinding dsDNA.

After completion of replication in an area, parent & daughter strand reforms dsDNA.

  • Start from particular site of initiation, where the replication complex is formed.
  • Always complete, to maintain genetic stability within organism
  • Ensure high fidelity, so involves many proofreading procedures
  • Synthesis of new DNA requires four dNTPs, enzymes & magnesium.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 35, page number 361

questions.text: A 17 year old male having microcytic anaemia is found to have abnormal beta globin chain (Haemoglobin constant spring) that is 172 amino acid long instead of normal 141 amino acids. Which of the following point mutation is likely happen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Mutation in the normal termination codon with another codon which code for specific amino acid leads to formation of abnormal long polypeptide chain.
  • Termination codons are: UAA, UAG, UGA.
  • Option A: Mutation in CGA (Code for arginine) to UGA (termination code) result in replacement of arginine into stop synthesis of peptide chain. It will result in formation of short polypeptide chain.
  • Option B: GAU & GAC both code for aspartate, so it will result in no change in polypeptide chain.
  • Option C: Mutating in UAA (termination codon) to CAA (code for glutamine) in beta globin mRNA causes insertion of glutamine at that point. It will continue extending the protein chain until stop codon comes in mRNA and results in formation of abnormal long polypeptide chain.
  • Option D: Mutation in GCA (code for alanine) to GAA (code for glutamate) would not change the size of polypeptide chain and protein product. Instead it will lead to change in amino acid at that particular site only which may result in abnormal protein product.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 37, page number 394
